contentrichtext.text: {{original research|date=November 2012}} {{manual|date=November 2012}} In [[computing]], '''XCOPY''' is a [[command (computing)|command]] used on [[PC DOS]], [[MS-DOS]], [[OS/2]], [[Microsoft Windows]], and related operating systems for copying multiple [[computer file|files]] or entire directory trees from one [[directory (file systems)|directory]] to another and for copying files across a [[computer network|network]]. XCOPY stands for ''extended copy'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=kb;en-us;100012 |title=Windows NT File System Files |date=2006-11-01 |work=Microsoft Help and Support |publisher=Microsoft}}</ref> and was created as a more functional file copying utility than the [[copy (command)|copy]] command found in these operating systems. XCOPY first appeared in DOS 3.2. ==Example== Create a new directory by copying all contents of the existing directory, including any files or subdirectories having the "hidden" or "system" attributes and empty directories. <source lang="dos"> xcopy e:\existing e:\newcopy /s /e /i /h </source> If the directory names include blank signs(spaces), the names can be put in quotation marks. <source lang="dos"> xcopy "D:\Documents and Settings\MY.USERNAME\My Documents\*" "E:\MYBACKUP\My Documents\" /D/E/C/Y </source> Copy entire drive in to a mapped network drive while ignoring any errors in network restartable mode. <source lang="dos"> xcopy *.* z:\Netmirror /E /V /C /F /H /Y /Z 1>out.txt 2>err.txt </source> Copy a single file without prompt if it is a file or a directory <source lang="dos"> cmd /c echo F | xcopy "c:\directory 1\myfile" "c:\directory 2\myfile" </source> ==Deprecation== While still included in [[Windows Vista]], Xcopy has been [[deprecated]] in favor of [[Robocopy]], a more powerful copy tool, which is now built into the operating system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/matt_pietrek/archive/2007/01/16/robocopy-built-into-vista.aspx |title=Robocopy built into Vista |last=Pietrek |first=Matt |authorlink=Matt Pietrek |date=2007-01-16 |work=Under The Hood (an MSDN blog)}}</ref> [[Windows 7]] <code>xcopy /?</code> does '''not''' claim that it is deprecated. ==Limitation== Experience has shown that Xcopy fails with an "insufficient memory" error when the path plus filename is longer than 254 characters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.terminally-incoherent.com/blog/2007/02/05/xcopy-insufficient-memory |title=Xcopy: Insufficient Memory|last=Maciak |first=Luke |authorlink=Luke Maciak |date=2007-02-05}}</ref> ==See
